column4: if you have to use f12 to start some boot-manager to select the internal drive, set the internal drive in BIOS as boot-device (with higher priority?). If linux asks to skip the external drives, because they couldn't be found, add "noauto" to their fstab-entries
that actually sounds good. but wouldnt noauto mean that i have to mount them manually? and my internal drive is set as the first drive to boot from
noauto in fstab prevents mounting at boot-time, it doesn't prevent automount later
that sounds like a perfect fix, hang on, let me do some googling
so for example: UUID=1d112679-6e31-481f-86eb-f7ec25756183 /media/Server2  ext3  errors=noauto,remount-rw,users,user  0  0
would this be correct?
no, noauto has nothing to do with errors
why "users,user" ?
well that means any user can mount, and user can write? right?
oh its group user
lol
man mount: "user: ordinary user can mount  [and only he can] unmount"  "users: allow every user to mount/unmount"
why not just "defaults,users,noauto" ?
and leave out the errors option?

well honestly i had it somewhat the way you are telling me before hand. then i lost so much faith in myself i downloaded storage device manager from repos. and it added that information in there just like that
and it was rated 4.5 stars
so i assumed it knew a little more than i did
i don't understand the error-option... why remount readwriteable, if there are some errors? usually you remount readonly (ro) for recovery.
well i took that out. like i said, that is what storage device manager did, not me
my next question for you. is why does it show under "Places" the device 2 times?
yet in /media/ there is only 1 mount point for each one
uh... that i don't know.
